content.question:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students design an experiment to determine the unknown dielectric constant <math alttext="kappa " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>κ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of a plastic material. A capacitor is created using two square aluminum plates of side length <math alttext="s equals 30 centimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that are separated by a distance <math alttext="d equals 1.0 millimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. This capacitor is placed in a circuit with an ideal <math alttext="6.0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-volt battery, a resistor of resistance <math alttext="R equals 500 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , voltmeter <math alttext="V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and an open switch <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. A <math alttext="1.0 millimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> thick piece of plastic is inserted between the aluminum plates. The distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that the plastic is inserted between the plates can be varied, and the voltmeter is used to measure the potential difference <math alttext="V sub C " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> across the capacitor. The switch is closed, and readings from the voltmeter are recorded as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The data are plotted to create the graph shown below.

The time <math alttext="t sub one half" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>1/2</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> shown above is the time for the capacitor to charge to half the potential difference of the battery.

(a) The potential difference across the capacitor as a function of time is modeled by the equation <math alttext="V sub C equals V sub max, end subscript, times, open parenthesis, 1 minus e raised to the negative t over R C, power, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>MAX</mtext></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>R</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , where <math alttext="V sub max equals 6 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">MAX</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> . Derive an expression for the capacitance <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the capacitor. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="t sub one half" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>1/2</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , and physical constants, as appropriate.

frqParts.text:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students design an experiment to determine the unknown dielectric constant <math alttext="kappa " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>κ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of a plastic material. A capacitor is created using two square aluminum plates of side length <math alttext="s equals 30 centimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that are separated by a distance <math alttext="d equals 1.0 millimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. This capacitor is placed in a circuit with an ideal <math alttext="6.0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-volt battery, a resistor of resistance <math alttext="R equals 500 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , voltmeter <math alttext="V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and an open switch <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. A <math alttext="1.0 millimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> thick piece of plastic is inserted between the aluminum plates. The distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that the plastic is inserted between the plates can be varied, and the voltmeter is used to measure the potential difference <math alttext="V sub C " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> across the capacitor. The switch is closed, and readings from the voltmeter are recorded as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The data are plotted to create the graph shown below.

The time <math alttext="t sub one half" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>1/2</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> shown above is the time for the capacitor to charge to half the potential difference of the battery.

(a) The potential difference across the capacitor as a function of time is modeled by the equation <math alttext="V sub C equals V sub max, end subscript, times, open parenthesis, 1 minus e raised to the negative t over R C, power, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>MAX</mtext></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>R</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , where <math alttext="V sub max equals 6 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">MAX</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> . Derive an expression for the capacitance <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the capacitor. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="t sub one half" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>1/2</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , and physical constants, as appropriate.

The data for <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t sub one half" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>1/2</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are recorded for several trials and the value of <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for each trial is calculated. The results are shown in the chart below.

<math alttext="x, in meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>m</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.050" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.050</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.15" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.25" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.25</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="t sub one half, in microseconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>1/2</mtext></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>μs</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.44" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.44</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.63" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.63</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.75" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.75</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.88" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.88</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="1.10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="C, in nanofarads" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>nF</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="1.27" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.27</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="1.82" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.82</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="2.16" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.16</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="2.54" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.54</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="3.17" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.17</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

(b) Plot the experimental value of the capacitance <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of the distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the graph below. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units if appropriate. Draw a straight line that best represents the data.

(c) The capacitor in the lab can be treated as two capacitors in parallel, one with the dielectric and one with air between the plates. Show that the capacitance can be expressed as <math alttext="C equals, the fraction epsilon sub 0, end subscript, times S, and denominator d, end fraction, times, open parenthesis, s plus, x times open parenthesis, kappa minus 1, close parenthesis, close parenthesis." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>κ</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> .
(d) Using the graph from part (b), calculate the value of the dielectric constant <math alttext="kappa " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>κ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> .

(e) The students now want to verify the value for the permittivity constant, <math alttext="epsilon sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> . Using the graph from part (b), calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="epsilon sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> .

(f) Assume the value found in part (e) is higher than the accepted value for the permittivity constant. State one possible physical reason for this error and explain how it could have caused this error.

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
